prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: GRB ToO Band 3
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
ToO setup to measure afterglow at semi-periodic intervals of GRB in band 3.
This ToO does not have a specific target, so a warning is generated regarding coordinates being 0.0 - this warning can be ignored.

prj:VisitConstraint.prj:note: Inititial observations determined by triggering - followups spaced roughly 10-20 after initial trigger. We defined all follow-up visit relative to the first observation to ensure a roughly equal spacing and that we still detect the afterglow in the last epoch.

Inititial observations determined by triggering - followups spaced roughly 10-20 after initial trigger. We defined all follow-up visit relative to the first observation to ensure a roughly equal spacing and that we still detect the afterglow in the last epoch.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: This is a continuum-only project to measure the featureless synchrotron spectrum of GRB afterglows at two different frequencies, so we apply for continuum-mode observations.

The GRB will be a point source for ALMA, and thus we can use the highest resolution ALMA offers without missing flux. GRB host galaxies are usually faint in the sub-mm. We do not expect a significant contamination to the GRB flux. The requested angular scale were only added as dummy values.

++++++ See also the attached PDF file ++++++
To estimate the cadence and the desired S/N, we use our expertise in sub-mm observations of GRB afterglows [14] and results from previous broadband modelling (e.g. Fig. 3). de Ugarte Postigo [14] showed that the peak of the afterglow spectrum crosses the sub-mm/mm regime a few days after the GRB. The exact time depends on various factors, such as outflow geometry and the conditions in the blast-wave. Figure 3 shows two distinct examples: GRB 130427A can be described by a two-component jet and variable microphysical parameters (both extensions to the standard afterglow model), while GRB 111215A can be described by a single jet in agreement with the standard afterglow model. Both examples have in common that the emission at more than 10 days after the burst constrains the emission after the peak frequency crossed the sub-mm regime. To accurately measure the slope after the crossing, we need at least three epochs separated by 10-20 days. Hence we need observations up to 60 days. At ~60 days, an afterglow with a peak flux of ~300 ?Jy has a flux of ~60 ?Jy at 92.5 GHz and a little bit less at 338.5 GHz. We would like to recover these ~60 ?Jy at least at 2 sigma confidence level at 92.5 GHz and at 1.5 sigma at 338.5 GHz. Hence we request an r.m.s. of 30 ?Jy and 40 ?Jy at 92.5 and 338.5 GHz, respectively.
At earlier epochs the S/N will be between 8-10. Such a high S/N is needed to fit the light curve and find a deviation from a simple power law model.

Same as in Control and Performance section
Inititial observations determined by triggering - followups spaced roughly 10-20 after initial trigger. We defined all follow-up visit relative to the first observation to ensure a roughly equal spacing and that we still detect the afterglow in the last epoch.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: This is a continuum-only project to measure the featureless synchrotron spectrum of GRB afterglows, so we apply for continuum-mode observations

The GRB will be a point source for ALMA, and thus we can use the highest resolution ALMA offers without missing flux. GRB host galaxies are usually faint in the sub-mm. We do not expect a significant contamination to the GRB flux. The requested angular scale were only added as dummy values.

++++++ See also the attached PDF file ++++++
To estimate the cadence and the desired S/N, we use our expertise in sub-mm observations of GRB afterglows [14] and results from previous broadband modelling (e.g. Fig. 3). de Ugarte Postigo [14] showed that the peak of the afterglow spectrum crosses the sub-mm/mm regime a few days after the GRB. The exact time depends on various factors, such as outflow geometry and the conditions in the blast-wave. Figure 3 shows two distinct examples: GRB 130427A can be described by a two-component jet and variable microphysical parameters (both extensions to the standard afterglow model), while GRB 111215A can be described by a single jet in agreement with the standard afterglow model. Both examples have in common that the emission at more than 10 days after the burst constrains the emission after the peak frequency crossed the sub-mm regime. At ~60 days, an afterglow with a peak flux of ~300 ?Jy has a flux of ~60 ?Jy at 92.5 GHz and a little bit less at 338.5 GHz. We would like to recover these ~60 ?Jy at least at 2 sigma confidence level at 92.5 GHz and at 1.5 sigma at 338.5 GHz. Hence we request an r.m.s. of 30 ?Jy and 40 ?Jy at 92.5 and 338.5 GHz, respectively.
At earlier epochs the S/N will be between 8-10. Such a high S/N is needed to fit the light curve and find a deviation from a simple power law model.

Same as in Control and Performance section
Inititial observations determined by triggering - followups spaced roughly 10-20 after initial trigger. We defined all follow-up visit relative to the first observation to ensure a roughly equal spacing and that we still detect the afterglow in the last epoch.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: GRBs are powered by stellar-mass black holes that eject matter at ultra-relativistic velocities. This makes them ideal laboratories to study particle acceleration processes. Up to now the Swift satellite has detected ~1000 GRB afterglows but only 20-30 were bright enough for extensive follow-ups from radio to X-ray wavelengths to provide crucial constraints on the radiation processes. These analyses were however limited to bright afterglows, which could introduce a bias in the relative importance of different radiation processes. Thanks to ALMA's supreme sensitivity, both the peak and the faint end of the GRB luminosity function could now be probed at sub-mm wavelengths. We propose to observe one GRB with a peak flux of ~300 ?Jy at 93 and 339 GHz at 5 different epochs each. The peak flux is about 1 dex fainter than of previously studied GRBs and more representative of the bulk of the GRB population. We will complement these observations with optical and NIR data to model the broadband spectral energy distribution. We will identify the dominant radiation process and characterise its key properties, study the ambient density profile and the dynamics of the ultra-relativistic jet.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
